senses.sense: Reduced form of 'so that', used to express purpose; in order that.
examples: I got an earlier train to work so I'd have plenty of time to prepare for the meeting.
Eat your broccoli so you can have dessert.

senses.sense: With the result that; for that reason; therefore.
examples: I was hungry, so I asked if there was any more food.
He ate too much cake, so he fell ill.
He wanted a book, so he went to the library.
“I need to go to the bathroom.” ― “So go!”

senses.sense: Used to connect previous conversation or events to the following question.
examples: So how does this story end?

senses.sense: Used to introduce a rhetorical question.
examples: “We'd like to visit but I don't know if we can afford a hotel.” — “So who's staying in a hotel? Stay with us.”

senses.sense: (archaic) Provided that; on condition that, as long as.
To the (explicitly stated) extent that.
examples: It was so hot outside that all the plants died.
He was so good, they hired him on the spot.

senses.sense: (informal) To the (implied) extent.
examples: I need a piece of cloth so  long. [= this long]
There are only so many hours in a day.

senses.sense: (informal) Very (positive clause).
examples: I feel so much better now.
I so nearly lost my temper.

senses.sense: (informal) Very (negative clause).
examples: It’s not so bad. [i.e. it's acceptable]

senses.sense: (slang, chiefly US) Very much.
examples: But I so  want to see the Queen when she visits our town!
That is so  not true!

senses.sense: In a particular manner.
examples: Place the napkin on the table just so. If that's what you mean, then say so; (or do so).

senses.sense: In the same manner or to the same extent as aforementioned; also.
examples: Just as you have the right to your free speech, so I have the right to mine.  Many people say she's the world's greatest athlete, but I don't think so.  "I can count backwards from one hundred." "So can I."
‘There're another two.’ ‘So there are.’

senses.sense: (with as): To such an extent or degree; as.
examples: so far as;  so long as;  so much as

senses.sense: True, accurate.
examples: That is so.
You are responsible for this, is that not so?

senses.sense: In that state or manner; with that attribute. A proadjective that replaces the aforementioned adjective phrase.
(dated, UK, slang) Homosexual.
examples: Is he so?

senses.sense: Used after a pause for thought to introduce a new topic, question or story, or a new thought or question in continuation of an existing topic.
examples: So, let's go home.
So, what'll you have?
So, there was this squirrel stuck in the chimney...
So, everyone wants to know – did you win the contest or not?

senses.sense: Used as a question to ask for further explanation of something said, often rhetorically or in a dismissive or impolite manner.
examples: "You park your car in front of my house every morning." — "So?"

senses.sense: Used as a meaningless filler word to begin a response to a question.
examples: What are you doing? / So I'm just fixing this shelf.
What time does the train leave? / So it leaves at 10 o'clock.
